speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux." And what if we wanted to invert to make the question?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Veux-tu." How did we say "a little," "a bit"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Un peu." [nasal 'un' sound] "Do you want a bit of cake"? So, "do you want a bit of," "of" is "D-E," "de." [schwa sound] Like we started "demander." [nasal 'a' sound] The "de" [schwa sound] of "demander" [nasal 'a' sound] or of "deform," "describe," is the same "de," [schwa sound] "of." So, "do you want a bit of cake"?

speaker: Teacher
text: So as a Spanish speaker, you must be careful now 'cause you have "te" in Spanish, but it's "de," "de" [schwa sound] in French. "Veux-tu un peu de gâteau"? "I want to order the cake"? "I want to order the cake"?

speaker: Student
text: Je veux, je veux commander le gâteau.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux commander le gâteau." [nasal 'a' sound] "I can confirm"? [nasal 'a' sound] "I can confirm"? [nasal 'a' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je peux confirmer." [nasal 'a' sound] "I can close the door"? And "close," we were getting it from an older version of "confirmer," [nasal 'a' sound] which was "confermer." [nasal 'a' sound] "I can close the door." "The door" like "the port." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je peux fermer la porte." [uvular R sound] How would "complication" be in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Compliquer." [nasal 'o' sound] Good. So this M of "com" [nasal 'o' sound] is also quite silent, not really pronounced. And, you know, it's the same as that N, actually, "con," [nasal 'o' sound] "com," [nasal 'o' sound] are actually the same addition, let's say. Just they end in an N or an M depending on the letter that comes afterwards. You'll notice before Ps, for example, we get an M. "Complicate," "compare." "Explanation" in French is "explication." "Explanation" is "explication" in French. So how would that be?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Explication." [nasal 'a' sound] Like the "inexplicable" we have in English, we don't say "inexplainable," no, but "inexplicable." So if you want to find the verb "to explain," you would go from there. You would go from "explication." [nasal 'a' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "To complicate." [nasal 'o' sound] "Expliquer," "to explain." And we see how these are built in the same way. Either "com" [nasal 'o' sound] or "ex" with "pliquer." "Compliquer." [nasal 'o' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Plier" literally means something like "folding." If something is "complicated," [nasal 'o' sound] it's all "folded up." If something is "explained," it's "ex-folded up," "unfolded." How was "you can"? Again, "you can," "you are able."

speaker: Teacher
text: Peux-tu expliquer un peu? [nasal 'un' sound] So it's very interesting to try to figure out what's going on behind the scenes in a word. How does it express its assigned meaning? If you make a habit of this, of dissecting words, you will remember better the vocabulary you come across by analyzing it rather than just trying to memorize it. And you will often find new verbs too. Like in "expliquer," "compliquer," [nasal 'o' sound] "dupliquer," which might mean? "Dupliquer"? What might that mean?

speaker: Teacher
text: "To duplicate." So, "dupliquer" actually means "to two-fold." "Two" like the number two, like in "duo," which is from Greek actually. So we have "du," like "duo," "two," "pliquer," "dupliquer." But "to fold," just "to fold" in French is slightly different. It loses this K sound we get in "pliquer." So "to fold" is just "plier," "plier."

speaker: Teacher
text: "P-L-I-E-R." So this "E-R," which is always showing us that it's two, no? "Plier," "two fold."

speaker: Teacher
text: "The trousers" or "the pants" are "le- Pantalon." [nasal 'a' and 'o' sounds] "Le pantalon." [nasal 'a' and 'o' sounds] And again, both of those Ns there in "pantalon" [nasal 'a' and 'o' sounds] are half silent, no? Not very strong at all. "Can you fold the pants"? "Can you fold the trousers"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Peux-tu plier le pantalon"? [nasal 'a' and 'o' sounds] "Late." "Late" in French is "tard."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tard." And this is spelled "T-A-R-D." So the final consonant in French, as we have been seeing, is rarely pronounced. "T-A-R-D," but we say "tard."

speaker: Teacher
text: Now, we also have this "tard" in English. Of course, not in all dialects of English, but we can say, like, "I'm arriving a bit tardy." No? This "tardy," we hear the D there that we don't pronounce in French. Means like "late." Or in "flame retardant," for example. A "flame retardant" delays fire. It makes "late" fire, no? So "T-A-R-D." "Tard." "Late." How might you say "a little late"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Un peu tard. [nasal 'un' sound] "Later" in French is "more late," or "plus late." Now, "plus" is the same word in French, only we will have the "ou" sound like in "tu," like in "you," which is "T-U." And we know that the consonant on the end of the word isn't likely to be pronounced, so how is "plus" going to sound in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Plus tard." "Plus tard." "I can reserve something later."

speaker: Student
text: Je peux reserver quelque chose plus tard.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je peux reserver quelque chose plus tard." How was "you can"?

speaker: Teacher
text: And if you want to say, "Can you?" Inverting for the question.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Peux-tu." "Can you organize something later"? "Can you organize something later"?

speaker: Student
text: Peux-tu... Peux-tu organiser quelque chose plus tard?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Peux-tu organiser quelque chose plus tard"? "Can you order something later"? "Can you order something later"?

speaker: Student
text: Peux-tu commander quelque chose plus tard?

speaker: Teacher
text: Peux-tu commander quelque chose plus tard? [nasal 'a' sound] Very good. "I want to reserve something a little later." "I want to reserve something a little later." So we begin with the first thought, "I want."

speaker: Student
text: Quelque chose un peu plus tard.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux reserver quelque chose un peu plus tard." [nasal 'un' sound] What was "to confirm," [nasal 'a' sound] again?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Fermer." Good. "Fermer," "to close." "Fermer à clé." "To close," "to key." "À clé," "to key." Means "to lock." "Fermer à clé," "to lock." Or "to close, to key," literally. "Fermer à clé."

speaker: Teacher
text: And "clé" has the E with the accent on it, which is why we hear it "clay" rather than "cleh," no? "Fermer à clé." "You can lock the door." "You can lock the door."

speaker: Student
text: Tu... Tu peux fermer à clé la porte.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu peux fermer à clé la porte." Or maybe more commonly, "tu peux fermer la porte à clé." "You can lock the door later." "You can lock the door more late," or "plus late." "You can lock the door later."

speaker: Student
text: Tu peux fermer à clé la porte plus tard.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu peux fermer à clé la porte plus tard." So, we saw "tard" is "late." Then, "plus tard," "plus late," is "later." You might also hear, "à plus tard," meaning, "see you later," "until later." "À plus tard."
